# Summary bar graphs {#sec-sum-bar-graphs} :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false}
::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** **✅ a categorical variable** ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](sum_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: :::: ## Description Bar graphs can summarize data by showing a statistic for each category. The x-axis lists the categories, and the y-axis shows the values. They can include error bars to show variation or confidence intervals. In `ggplot2`, we can create summary bar graphs with `geom_bar()`. ## Set up ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: Install packages. ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: Remove the missing values from `body_mass_g` and `island` in the `palmerpenguins::penguins` data and convert body mass in grams to kilograms (`body_mass_kg`). *We'll also reduce the number of columns in the `penguins` data for clarity.* ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} peng_sum_col <- palmerpenguins::penguins |> dplyr::select(body_mass_g, island) |> tidyr::drop_na() |> # divide the mass value by 1000 dplyr::mutate( body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000 ) |> dplyr::group_by(island) |> dplyr::summarise( avg_bmi_kg = mean(body_mass_kg) ) |> dplyr::ungroup() dplyr::glimpse(peng_sum_col) #> Rows: 3 #> Columns: 2 #> $ island Biscoe, Dream, Torgersen #> $ avg_bmi_kg 4.716018, 3.712903, 3.706373 ``` ::: ::: ## Grammar ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: - Create labels with `labs()` - Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` - Map `island` to `x` and `avg_bmi_kg` to `y` - *Inside* the `aes()` of `geom_col()`, map `island` to `fill` - *Outside* the `aes()` of `geom_col()`, remove the legend with `show.legend = FALSE` ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_sum_col <- labs( title = "Average Penguin Body Mass", subtitle = "What is the average penguin BMI per Island?", x = "Island", y = "Average Penguin Body Mass (kg)") ggp2_sum_col <- ggplot(data = peng_sum_col, aes(x = island, y = avg_bmi_kg)) + geom_col(aes(fill = island), show.legend = FALSE) ggp2_sum_col + labs_sum_col ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](sum_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/create_graph_sum_col-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: ## More Info Below is more information on `geom_bar()` vs. `geom_col()`. ### Identity vs. Count - The `geom_bar()` geom will also create grouped bar graphs, but we have to switch the `stat` argument to `"identity"`. ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = peng_sum_col, aes(x = island, y = avg_bmi_kg)) + geom_col(aes(fill = island), show.legend = FALSE, stat = "identity") + labs_sum_col ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](sum_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/show_stat_sum_col-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: ::: ### `geom_bar()` vs. `geom_col()`
- `geom_bar()` will map a categorical variable to the `x` *or* `y` and display counts for the discrete levels (see [`stat_count()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_bar.html) for more info) - `geom_col()` will map *both* `x` *and* `y` aesthetics, and is used when we want to display numerical (quantitative) values across the levels of a categorical variable. `geom_col()` assumes these values have been created in their own column (see [`stat_identity()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/stat_identity.html) for more info)
